newswire.title: A New Map for America
newswire.abstract: The 50-state model is holding the country back. It needs a new system, built around urban corridors.

comments.commentBody:
Parag Khanna must be applauded for proposing a radical solution to a vexing problem that has arisen from a historical quirk, i.e., how the states were created in the first place over two centuries ago.

However, there is no mention of Joel Garreau's nine-nation map of North America (not just the USA). Almost thiry years back, Professor Garreau saw that there were cultural and political similarities in these nine regions. Professor Khanna has taken it forward and brough it to the twenty-first century. I only wish he had referenced this pioneering work from the past.

For those interested, here are two links to the nine nation proposal:

http://www.nytimes.com/roomfordebate/2014/07/03/where-do-borders-need-to...

https://www.google.com/search?q=garreau+nine+nations&espv=2&biw=...

Travis Dove for The New York Times
Travis Dove for The New York Times
Travis Dove for The New York Times

newswire.abstract: Donald Trump lacks the skills that make being onstage fun. Answering hecklers can be a pleasure for a performer, and “Throw ‘em out!” just doesn’t impress.

comments.commentBody:
"These are the disaffected. The disenfranchised. The disdainful."

Income inequality is very high and is recognized as a significant factor affecting millions who are either unemployed or under-employed. It is instructive to recall that all revolutions - French, Russian, or other more minor ones - are preceded by great disparity in society. The top 1%, or royalty in the earlier cases, run the risk of being targeted in violent revolutions unless they are smart enough to help facilitate a drastic reduction in the inequality. It will behoove them to voluntarily take on the burden of additional taxes before matters run out of control.

I don't think we are the point of a violent revolution in America but the seething anger that has propelled Trump and Sanders is real. It is time to remedy this dangerous trend and restore the middle class in order for ALL, including the top 1%, to survive.

newswire.title: How ‘Empowerment’ Became Something for Women to Buy
newswire.abstract: The corporate vision of female strength profits from the same old power dynamics.

comments.commentBody:
"People who talk empowerment are, by definition, already there." It is rarely "defined by the people who actually need it. "

The political equivalent of this would be the American way of trying to impose humanitarian values and democracy in various parts of the world. While laudable as goals, they often reek of paternalistic imposition.

Neither "empowerment" nor "democracy" can be imposed purely from the top down or from the outside-in. It has to be accompanied by a bottom-up, local, and internal movement that comes from those seeking these goals. Absent an inside-out component it is doomed to fail.

newswire.title: The Rich Live Longer Everywhere. For the Poor, Geography Matters.
newswire.abstract: In some parts of the country, adults with the lowest incomes die on average as young as people in much poorer nations like Rwanda, and their life spans are getting shorter.

comments.commentBody:
"New York has a high rate of social spending for low-income residents and has been aggressive in regulating trans fats and smoking."

It is clear that public spending and government regulations can help people live longer and healthier. It follows that those who favor such guvmint intervention the least - basically the red states - and the underfunded urban pockets in the blue states have the lowest life expectancy.

These results should show the hollowness of the GOP's only-tax-cutting and slahing-public-funding strategies to be, literally, deadly.

newswire.abstract: April is the cruelest month, especially since the gory “Game of Thrones” is back.

comments.commentBody:
"Oftentimes, they don’t want to meet you; they just want proof that they met you."

We are constantly taking videos and photographs on our vacation so we can enjoy them later. What about now?
We are always watching a game or show on TV so we can talk about it tomorrow when we meet a coworker at the water cooler. Why not get into the show or game and enjoy the moment?
We tend to take pictures of our food at restaurants for posting on Instagram. Why not simply savor it at that moment?

Many of us have forgotten to live in the moment, choosing to live for the future and others.

newswire.title: Building a Better Father
newswire.abstract: When a man loses his reserve, he gains so much more.

comments.commentBody:
Ron Fournier, Paul Ryan, Adam LaRoche and others like them are indeed lucky to be able to spend time with their family, especially kids.

However, they are in the distinct minority, not because men prefer not to spend time with their family, although that is part of the cultural milieu, but because the vast majority do not have the time or energy to do so. We do not have a national policy of providing family leave. Some progressive states and employers provide maternity leave, that too for very short periods, but even fewer provide for parental - read, paternity - leave.

Besides, a large segment of Americans work multiple jobs to make ends meet, robbing them of the valuable time they could have spent with their kids and family. And here we are, even today, debating whether or not to raise the minimum wage to let it get closer to a living wage.

While I appreciate Bruni's column devoting attention to the issue of father's spending time with their kids, I am afraid that absent a national policy in regards parental leave and minimum wage, many father's are doomed to be distant from their kids.

newswire.abstract: On abortion as on so much else, Mr. Trump makes comments seemingly at random, then backs off if he’s criticized.

comments.commentBody:
From the time he came gliding down an escalator to launch his bid for the nomination, he has been a showman, nothing more nothing less. And, the corollary to that is that audience size and preferences are crucial for being successful in show business. So it should come as no surprise that he has no knowledge of political issues or guiding principles. He is constantly seeking immediate gratification in terms of the number of people who fawn on him. Not any different from the Kardashians. Who, by the way, are famous for just being famous. Of course the problem is that, unlike the Kardashians who seek fawning platitudes, he is seeking to be the nominee for the office of the President of the United States.

What is the solution? Go to the polls, mobilize voters, and help someone else on the Democratic ticket win. But until then,sit back and enjoy the show.

taxonomies.name: What Is This Thing Called Populism? (05conversation)

newswire.byline: By ARTHUR C. BROOKS and GAIL COLLINS
newswire.title: What Is This Thing Called Populism?
newswire.abstract: Is the economy the driving force? Nationalism? Arthur C. Brooks and Gail Collins argue over the meaning of the rise of Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders.

comments.commentBody:
Poor Gail Collins! I am sure she's thankful it is only once a week.

Here are some of the priceless comments by Arthur Brooks in today's conversation:

1. "And thank God California doesn’t have more than two senators."
Given a chance he'll either throw California out of the union or at least change the number of House members representing California.

2. "a better explanation for Trump’s rise is the simple fact that our economy has created effectively zero percent economic growth for the bottom four-fifths of the population since the Great Recession."
What he really wanted to say was that Obama has not done his job in helping jobs growth. Of course he fails to say who caused the Great Depression, but given that was during the watch of his friend GWB, he'd rather remain mum on that issue.

3. "But I’ve never heard anybody say, “I hate the fact that there are a lot of minorities in the movies today.”
Obviously he has not heard the many artists of different ethnicity - Black, Hispanic, Indian, Chinese - in Hollywood write and speak about how difficult it is for them to get a job playing a person from their own community. I recommend Arthur Brooks to expand the range of his reading before pontificating so wildly.

4. "President Obama sort of tried that in the early years of his administration. It worked poorly."
Even in the face of data that the Obama stimulus helped create jobs and save million f automobile related jobs, Arthur Brooks prefers to keep his head in the sand.

newswire.title: The Politics of Backlash
newswire.abstract: Another two decades of neo-liberal, reward-the-rich politics will lead to a breakdown in society.

comments.commentBody:
"Equality may demand the restraint of the liberty of those who wish to dominate."

There are many who have written about the notion that one's individual liberty has to be viewed within the ambit of the community's liberty. Nearly a century ago A. G. Gardiner (known by his pen name Alpha of the Plough) wrote:

" You have submitted to a curtailment of private liberty in order that you may enjoy a social order which makes your liberty a reality."

In other words one's individual liberty is heavily dependent on the social contract and absent the social contract the concept of individual liberty loses its meaning.

There is dangerous trend today, particularly in right wing America, wherein the notion of a social contact is decried as useless or false. Recall the umbrage heaped on Elizabeth Warren and President Obama when the made reference to the fact that any one's success is not just the outcome of that person's hard work but a combination of that person's hard work embedded in a civil society that provides infrastructural support.

The current election cycle has, once again, brought out these differences in a stark manner. It is now up to the progressives to continue pushing their message and mobilizing voters. That is the only sure way to keep this governing philosophy alive.

And now that I think of it thus, it is all very clear. Aah! Thank you Donald for helping me understand these subtleties.

And that is why she deserves to be punished. But what about the man who must have been involved to make her pregnant? Obviously the woman seduced him into doing the unimaginable and hence cannot be held responsible. Besides, being a man provides immunity from a lot of things.

Which is why The Donald can say anything, shoot people on the street, ask his supporters to punch opponents in their face, talk ill of Megyn Kelly or Carly Fiorina, and not be held responsible for those attitudes or statements. After all, he's a man.

newswire.title: Dude, Where’s My City?

related_urls.suggested_link_text: The Cities on the Sunny Side of the American Economy

newswire.abstract: In Seattle, job growth is steroidal. But I ignore the usual measurements of what makes a city robust. Could Kramer from ‘Seinfeld’ live here?

comments.commentBody:
First NYC became impossible to live in unless you're willing to live in hole in the wall. Then Boston, and Philadelphia and Washington DC. The flyover parts of America were flown over when San Francisco became too expensive. Just a few days back I read the story of a guy who moved into SF and the only place he could afford was a box in his friend's living room.

https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2016/03/29/man-moves-...

This is, at least in part, the result of the wide inequality in wealth and income distributions. No one grudges the other person his/her Cadillac, but when I cannot even own and drive a used Yugo, something is terribly wrong. We need a revolution, not the French or Russian types, but one that reverses these unjust and untenable distributions.

I hate to end on a political note, but I have to. You and I have the chance to elect those that will help reverse this trend this November. America, are you up to the task?

comments.commentBody:
"For example, academic research shows that rather than deep cuts, Tea Party voters actually favor government programs, as long as they perceive a benefit for themselves."

This column is excellent and should be part of any future analysis on first the rise of the Tea Party and then The Donald. This entire community has no empathy, they can only think of their own welfare. Anything and everything is viewed through the lens of "what's in it for me." They are anti-government until they or one of their own loses a job. And then unemployment insurance and SNAP become important. If "someone else" was unemployed it was only because s/he was lazy. Cliven Bundy and his ilk are a living example of this warped philosophy. He has his cattle graze on federal land but will not pay for it.

newswire.title: The Republican Gun-Free Zone
newswire.abstract: If you want to be safe from being shot by a well-armed Donald Trump or Ted Cruz, go to the G.O.P.’s convention.

comments.commentBody:
After the massacre in Paris, The Donald has famously said, "“You know what? If I’m in that room and let’s say we have two or five or 40 people with guns, we’re going to do a lot better because there’s going to be a shootout."

This reminded me of a guy who was worried that there might be a bomb on the flight he would be taking. He decided to carry a bomb himself under the logic that the odds of a flight having two people carrying bombs was infinitesimally smaller than that of one person carrying one bomb.

Welcome to the world of The Donald and the Second Amendment aficionados.

Notwithstanding this upside down logic, they are smart enough to recognize that they do not want guns at places where there is a public debate, such as at the Republican National Convention. Unfortunately the secret service took a public stand of not allowing guns at this convention and provided cover for these chicken-hawk politicians. I'd have loved to hear Ted I-eat-my-bacon-smoked-on-a-barrel Cruz wax eloquent about how safe he feels with a thousand people carrying guns at the convention. This ought to show the world the double standards applied by these chicken-hawks. They are for guns all over the place, anywhere and anytime, but not where they may be endangered.

Wake up America! Smell the coffee! Vote these bums out! That power is in our hands.

newswire.abstract: To the Obama administration, the new data is seen as evidence that there has been pent-up demand for the policy signed into law by the president.

comments.commentBody:
It is hardly surprising that the newly insured "were sicker, used more medical care and had higher medical costs than those who already had coverage." The reason they did not buy healthcare, in large part, was because they could either not afford it or were shut out by pre-existing conditions. But since Obamacare was enacted into law they can now enter the marketplace.
I fully understand that my annual cost may have gone up as a result of that and may continue to go up even further. But I view that as my civic duty to help others so that everyone can gain access to healthcare. Besides, those who were earlier shut out of the healthcare market would have gone to emergency care raising our collective cost in a different manner. I'd like to know if that has decreased. And if so, the increased cost has to be seen as an offset as a decrease in the cost of providing emergency care.

comments.commentBody:
As the saying goes, "Power corrupts, absolute power absolutely corrupts." Trump knows very little and is not nuanced. He will centralize as much power as he can, all in the name of making America strong and respected again. And just like his business dealings there will be murky and shady aspects to his administration. And we will be in a far worse place four years into his presidency. If you thought that GWB was bad, just imagine how much worse we'll be with Trump at the helm. He is piqued that Germany is not toeing his line, just bomb them and they'll respect us. He does not like Iran, why not just send a couple of the many nukes we have. After all they're rotting in a silo somewhere.
Be afraid, be very afraid.

newswire.abstract: The party establishment abandoned its most faithful voters, blue-collar workers who faced economic pain while donors, lawmakers and lobbyists prospered.

comments.commentBody:
Remember the book "What's the matter with Kansdas?" from about a decade ago? One of the arguments presented in that book was that social conservatives voted for Republicans, even though they are voting against their economic interests just because their social agenda was aligned with the party's. However, the social changes over the past decade have essentially run against them and so right now all that these people have to focus on is their economic welfare. And finally they realized that the Republicans did not represent their interests but that of those in the top tier. Their natural tendency would have been to swing to the Democratic party but instead they saw Trump peddling his wares. And even though he was selling false promises that were total nonsense, these folks supported him.
And that is how Trump is where he is. Until these people realize that he is a chimera, they'll support him. They do not realize as yet that their true benefactor is Bernie Sanders. And the reason is because they do not understand or like the word socialism. They do not realize we already have a social safety net and are in a social democracy.
So the fog in Kansas has not yet fully cleared. That may take another four years or so.

You'll say that a number of Syrian refugees are involved and represents a huge human tragedy. Yes, I agree. But that human tragedy would not have been averted or slowed down with greater American involvement. Chances are it would have become another quagmire, just like Iraq, costing America far more in terms of in lives and money. So, think about that when you recommend American involvement all over the world. Sometimes sitting out and standing still is a good strategy.

newswire.abstract: Brussels survived this week’s terror attacks, but it may not survive climate change.

comments.commentBody:
Kristof hits the nail on the head in noting that "The human brain evolved so that we systematically misjudge risks and how to respond to them."

Humans don't pay attention to the slow creeping events that, in the long run, have a far greater deleterious effect than a spectacular but infrequent event. Moreover, often our response to these spectacular but infrequent events is misguided and out of proportion. The so-called "war-on-terror" initiated by GWB after the 9/11 attack is a case in point. No one denies that the attack was horrific. But did we have to respond with a "war-on-terror" or invade Iraq in its wake? A more rational response would not have ratcheted up to the point where we are today.

On the other hand, when we are informed by a respected scientist that climate change is more imminent and will likely affect us sooner, we yawn.

The human mind does indeed misjudge the risks. But should not our politicians guide us better?

newswire.title: The Middle-Age Surge
newswire.abstract: The image of midlife as a time of crisis is almost the opposite of what this period in life is really about.

comments.commentBody:
Some are fortunate to "turn midlife into a rebirth" and replace career advancement with advancing relationships.
But for many the issue still is how to make ends meet, how to continue to be a contributing agent, how to maintain self-respect and personal dignity.
I am sure David has seen, if not met, the people who stand at traffic lights with messages pleading for a little help. These are not young or old people; they are mostly middle-aged. Clearly our society and economy have passed over them and they have overcome personal shame to stand with that plea written on a piece of cardboard.
Their numbers have gone up suggesting that they do not fit this author's rosier picture. Clearly we need a political adjustment that focuses on people and jobs and their dignity.

newswire.abstract: The Obama administration has bent over backward to accommodate religious objectors, but they won’t take yes for an answer.

comments.commentBody:
This case is a perfect example of how far zealots will go to make sure that women's rights are abrogated. No one is forcing those with string religious convictions to encourage or fund abortions; all they are being asked is to declare their objection to this practice. Once they object, they have to step aside and let others do what is lawful, i.e., allow women the right to choose. But stepping aside is not what these zealots want to do; they want to step on others' toes and insist their own religious view be the ONLY one that ALL should follow.
Crying foul and loudly proclaiming that their rights are being trampled upon even as they trample upon others' rights is their time-trusted strategy. Shame upon them!

newswire.abstract: The current political crisis shows that we must constantly struggle for what we choose to be as a country.

comments.commentBody:
Without naming The Donald (because of his promise from a few months back) Charles Blow notes that his messages are hollow and "says little even as it promises much."
Those supporting him buy into this message just like they have been buying into the GOP's message for the past 30+ years: just work hard and the monied class will invest in our economy creating jobs for all of us.
This equally hollow, and now disproven message reminds me of a truism in construction: you need a strong foundation on which to build a skyscraper. And if anyone ought to know this, the man who claims to build the best skyscrapers ought to.

newswire.title: On Invincible Ignorance
newswire.abstract: The Republican Party may be in for some soul-searching, but so far its leaders remain in denial.

comments.commentBody: Speaker Ryan, Li'l Marco, John let-us-all-get-along Kasich and others say that unlike Drumpf, who speaks a coarse and divisive language, they prefer a positive  message. And therein lies their problem. Their sweet messages uttered in dulcet tones are just that; hollow words that do nothing to help the middle class expand their opportunities. And now their trusted base is revolting because they are revolted by the same-old same-old policies - cut taxes for those in the top tier, expand security on the southern border, defund Obamacare, Planned Parenthood and make sure all women carry to full term,  cut back on SNAP, and many others in similar vein. None of these prescriptions have ever helped anyone outside of the top tier. And now the chickens are coming home to roost, and their leader is not Foghorn Leghorn but Living-in-a-Fog-of-Lies-with-no-Legs Drumpf.

And it is this hollow speech sand action that has directly led to the ascent of The Donald.
And now like the cowering mice Speaker Ryan and his friends cower in the shadow of The Donald.

newswire.title: The Elements of Trumpism
newswire.abstract: How Trump’s rise illustrates the pull of authoritarianism.

comments.commentBody:
Ross Douthat is living in a world that I do not recognize.
For starters he writes that "our presidency is increasingly imperial." Who is he talking about? President Obama? The one who has been blocked by the Greedy Old Party at every turn? Imperial? Hardly.
For the main course he suggests that "there are basic norms that both parties and every major politician claim to honor and respect." This is as false as tofurkey is turkey. He conveniently overlooks 7+ years of a Repugnant led blockade that was more effective than the blockade of Cuba. Seven years that, in spite of that blockade, has reversed the economic chaos unleashed upon us by Bush 2.
And lastly for dessert he sweetly tells us that he has "spent a long time being anti-anti-Trump: not rooting for him to win." What he fails to tell us is that he has had a big hand in the evolution and creation of Trump. For seven long years Douthat has railed against Obama and fostered conditions conducive to the birth of a potty-mouthed Trump. And now he wants us to believe that he is really not rooting for him, just "appreciating his truth-telling on certain issues." How convenient.
This is a three course meal that I want no part of. Ross, you cooked the meal and you should eat it. At the very least you should proudly acknowledge being its facilitator, if not creator.

newswire.abstract: Stop trying to reason with Republicans. It has never worked before, and it won’t start working now.

comments.commentBody: I too agree that the President has the right to nominate a qualified person to the SCOTUS. But here is the problem as I see it. Given the publicly stated intransigence of the Senate Repugnants, why would a candidate who aspires to be on the SCOTUS accept that nomination now. S/he can expect the Senate Repugnants to drag their feet and the nominee's name through mud, just to spite Obama. I have no suggestion how to avoid this conundrum.

newswire.abstract: Mr. Trump’s xenophobia and racism are right at home in the Republican party.

comments.commentBody:
At first they birth the Tea party and are thrilled with the mid-term wins in 2010. They happily applaud when Rush Limbaugh, Glenn beck and others silently stoke the fires of racism. The remain silent when The Donald raises questions about Obama's birth certificate and educational accomplishments. They actively block any meaningful legislation that would make it easier (mind you, not make it easy, but just a tad easier) for the under-privileged in this country during the mini depression. An most recently they actively flout their constitutional duty to vet the nominee forwarded by President Obama. And now make weak statements countering The Donald's unwillingness to distance himself from David Duke.
If these actions are not anti-national (I did not want to use the word treasonous although that pops in my head from time to time), I have no idea what anti-national is. And they are our elected representatives. OMG.

comments.commentBody: It continues to amaze me that conservatives who are so much in favor of a smaller government, one that does not intrude into an individual's right to liberty and the pursuit of happiness, are adamant that the government must intrude in a woman's personal choice. No one is asking or forcing any one else to have an abortion. All we are asking is for their right to choose as a part of an individual's right to liberty and pursuit of happiness. Those who do not favor abortion are at full liberty not to undergo that procedure.

comments.commentBody:
Any bill regulating the size of an airplane seat in the economy section must also include a clause that links the size of the seat in the business/first class as a ratio of the economy class seat size. In other words, say, for instance that the business/first class seat cannot be bigger than 1.2 times that of the economy class seat. Those flying business/first class will clamor for (and rightly so) for bigger seats and we, in the economy class, will benefit because of the linking of these two seat sizes.
Give the uber rich what they want as long as the poorer folk have a decent fraction of it.

newswire.abstract: Europe knows that democracies can collapse. It watches Trump with memories of when the sky darkened.

comments.commentBody: Lost in this column is the role of income inequality birthed by of St. Reagan and midwifed by his successors. As I've noted many times, such inequality is often a precursor to revolutions. And Trump may be the most unpalatable but is the less virulent form of such a revolution. At least now I hope Americans will wake up and try to reduce income inequality and rebuild a strong robust middle class.

newswire.abstract: The nature of marriage is changing, and that is contributing to income inequality, research shows.

comments.commentBody:
There is a schism in American households that is caused by the phenomenon described in this column. Men and women in the educated strata tend to marry within that strata just like those in the under educated strata do so within their own strata. In short this will lead to a cleaving in our society wherein there will be a group of highly educated (and hence more in high skill professions) couples even as there will under educated (and hence in lower skill jobs) couples.
As the column notes, the Don Drapers will no longer marry their secretaries any more than the Donna Drapers are likely to marry mangers.

These double standards apply to even more basic things like attire, hair style and such. The day we will readily accept a 70 year old woman with disheveled hair, no make up and a rumpled skirt as a normal person campaigning will be a major step forward. But I am afraid that that day is still in the distant future.

comments.commentBody:

But Sarah Palin is not a good test case for the double standards because it was (and continues to be) too easy to show her emptiness. All it took Ms. Couric was to ask Ms. Palin the names of the newspapers or magazines she had read.
However Hillary Clinton is better example. We'll have to see if the media and public adopt double standards in judging her on her looks, attire and other less relevant parameters.

newswire.abstract: The delegate math leaves open a path to victory, but he would need to start winning on March 15.

comments.commentBody:
Marco Rubio listened to the pundits who asked him to take Donald Trump head on and he did just that yesterday. And today most of the pundits are calling him a winner because he out-shouted Donald Trump.
If this were a college debate, the judges would have asked both teams to shut up and go home because a debate is where ideas are presented and vetted; it is not a shouting match. More decibels does not lead to winning, although most pundits are calling Rubio the winner just for that reason.
Only Ramesh Ponnuru, senior editor at the conservative National Review, called it correctly. He noted that “This is degenerating into a food fight where no one looks good.”

newswire.title: Smartphone Era Politics
newswire.abstract: People are outpaced by forces they can't grasp. In political discourse, reasonableness dies, provocation works.

comments.commentBody: There are big differences between babble and information just like there are big differences between pseudo-science and real-science. Today's hyper-connectivity has enabled the quick and easy dissemination of babble and pseudo-science alongside information and real-science. If we took every item posted on FB or every tweet sent out, we'd be inundated and drowning. We need to learn to sift the chaff from the grain. I am hopeful that more and more Americans will acquire those skills in the future.

newswire.abstract: As a young Pakistani, Rafiullah Kakar hated the United States and backed the Taliban. But he changed.

comments.commentBody:
Thank you for this story of one person who seems to have turned his life around. But generalizing from this one success story is tenuous.
There are two important shifts that are needed, only one of which is addressed by Kristof in this column. Almost passingly he notes that "we should also put more pressure on countries like Saudi Arabia to stop financing extremist madrasas in poor countries in Africa and Asia." This is probably the most important shift in US policy that can counter the global recruiting of young educated men. The Saudis promote the most virulent and fundamentalist form of Islam. It is unconscionable that the US is allied with them.
The second shift in the US policy, not mentioned in this column, is to stop funding Pakistan in the name of fighting Islamist extremism. The Northwest frontier which is close to Afghanistan (and includes Balochistan) is a lawless region. On any given day you can buy any weapon you wish to in this region. Much of the arms that are given by the US to the Pakistani army ends up in this market.
So, while it is satisfying to read the success of one Pakistani, there will not even be a dent in the recruiting of young Pakistani men by the likes of AQ and ISIS until the Saudis stop spreading Wahabiism and the US stops sending arms to the Pakistani army.

newswire.abstract: Donald Trump and Pope Francis have much in common.

comments.commentBody:
For a change I couldn't agree more with Douthat, but not for the reason he may believe.
Even though I do not agree with many of the Church's dogmas, I believe that Pope Francis is a great human being unlike The Donald. The Holy See stands for and promotes humanity unlike Trump.
So what is it that I agree with Douthat? "well). Both show a "mastery of the contemporary media environment." But here too they diverge. Pope Francis uses the media to show a softer side of Catholicism whereas Trump uses the media to denigrate the person du-jour. Yesterday it was the Mexicans, today it is veterans, and tomorrow it'll be gays.

newswire.title: How to Bring the Supreme Court Back Down to Earth
newswire.abstract: In nominating Justice Antonin Scalia’s successor, President Obama has a chance to reconnect the court with the people it is supposed to serve.

comments.commentBody:
As a chess player Obama should nominate Judge Srikanth Srinivasan of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit or Judge Jane L. Kelly of the Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Both of them were confirmed by a thumping majority with no dissenting vote. And that too very recently. One is an Indian America who will add yet another dimension on the diversity factor, whereas the other is a woman who will continue to bridge the gender gap on the SCOTUS bench. And, if the republicans try to thwart this nomination, it will be very clear what their objective is. And that will have a direct bearing on the general election which should favor the Democrats. Either President Sanders or Clinton can nominate whoever they want.
Checkmate!

newswire.abstract: He made constitutional theory sexy.

comments.commentBody:
"Liberals, meanwhile, have struggled to rally around a coherent alternative language in which to talk about the Constitution."

I am baffled that people don't seem to or want to understand that there is "just no reliable way to figure out the intentions of long dead people about matters they had never thought about."

Take for example the contentious arguments surrounding the second amendment. Di they know that automatic rifles will be invented? Did they know that governments will have missiles in their arsenal? The idea that the right to own a single-shot rifle of the 1700s should be interpreted as the right to own nuclear bombs is not just silly, it is preposterous.

And therein lies the fundamental problem with those, like Scalia, favoring originalism.

Silly, preposterous or otherwise Scalia managed to breathe new life into the originalist view. And for that he will be remembered.

taxonomies.name: Trump, Sanders and the Revolt Against Decadence (31douthat)

newswire.title: Trump, Sanders and the Revolt Against Decadence
newswire.abstract: Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders, in very different ways, are telling us we don’t have to settle for things as they are.

comments.commentBody:
Where do I begin Mr. Douthat? Well at the every beginning, and that would be your title. Lumping Trump and Sanders as leaders of a revolt is incorrect. One has a policy position and some prescriptions; the other keeps making wild promises.

Grudgingly, very grudgingly, you note that the "worst-case scenarios of the post-Great Recession era haven’t materialized" and that "Obamacare is limping along without an imminent death spiral, and health care costs aren’t rising as fast as feared" and that "The deficit has fallen a bit, and inflation is extraordinarily low" and "Illegal immigration rates are down." Nowhere do you mention who was the President during this 7+ years when all of these things came to pas. And, may I add, in the face of the most obstructionist Congress and pundits (like you) railing against the President.

Isn't it time for you to take a bow to your President. Yes Mr. Dothat he is YOUR President. Acknowledge that, at least grudgingly, and take a bow.

newswire.title: The Anxieties of Impotence
newswire.abstract: The sense of powerlessness that is sweeping our nation and the world can only be addressed by rebuilding our institutions.

comments.commentBody:
David Brooks notes, "To address these problems we need big, responsible institutions (power centers) that can mobilize people, cobble together governing majorities and enact plans of actions. In the U.S. context that means functioning political parties and a functioning Congress."

After years of facilitating the growth of the Tea Party whose only goal is to destroy any civil institution, now Mr. Brooks seems to see value in "responsible institutions" and "governing majorities." Where was he in 2008 when Mitch McConnell wished for a one-term President? Where was he when Congressman Joe Wilson accuse the President of lying? Where was he when the LImbaughs and Coulters of the world were savaging these very institutions?

newswire.title: Ways to Be Free
newswire.abstract: On paper, the world is freer than ever. Yet minds feel more crimped, fear more pervasive, escape more elusive.

comments.commentBody:
Cohen writes, "I don’t know if the world is freer than a half-century ago. On paper, it is."
This is a perfect example of a westerner who already enjoyed freedom and is able to use his limited resources - although they are not limited from the Afghan's perspective - to roam around without a care.
Ask an Afghani or anyone from what used to called the second and third world and they'll have a different perspective.
So, even as you speak about freedom being replaced by fear, at the very least please acknowledge that it is a western - or what used to be called as first world - vision and not a universal vision.

newswire.title: America the Unfair?
newswire.abstract: We need to leverage populist frustration into constructive postelection policy. It’s been done before.

comments.commentBody:
Nicholas Bloom suggests that raising the tax on the uber rich and wealthy is a no-brainer. Martin Gilens sees campaign finance reform as the centerpiece of any meaningful reform.

On any given day these two knowledgeable professors would have had the country's ears. But these are different times. Tweets are the new way to communicate. Instant gratification drives people's choices.

Today's right-wing populism fueled by the likes of Trump sees America as being corrupted by liberal social values and immigrants rather than seeing it as a country that was corrupted by slavery and is moving towards a more perfect union.

newswire.abstract: In many ways, the party’s strategy of resistance to all things Democratic has backfired.

comments.commentBody:
Read the words used by William Kristol in advocating for no compromise with then President Clinton carefully. His main and only goal was to defeat the healthcare proposal and in the process hand a defeat to President Clinton. There was no attempt to evaluate the merits of the healthcare proposal and its potential effect on expanding coverage.

This test of purity got codified in the ensuing years to the point that "During the Obama years, the Kristol strategy has become fully operational for Republicans dealing with administration proposals." The depth to which this attitude became entrenched in the Republican DNA is best seen in Mitch McConnell's famous statement, “The single most important thing we want to achieve is for President Obama to be a one-term president.”

All of which brings me to the upcoming election ins 2016. There is a simple way to end this dogmatic approach - vote for a Democrat and also help mobilize voting in your community. It is high time that we the people demand that our representatives actually represent us and not merely try to unseat an opponent.

newswire.title: What If?
org_facet: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
newswire.abstract: What if the eras of the E.U., high growth in China, expensive oil and newly independent nations’ economic foundations are all over?

comments.commentBody:
What if Bashar Assad was deposed and a civilian government came into existence?
What if Bibi wen away and his successor forged a two-state solution with the Palestinians?
What if a Democrat won the White House and pushed through legislation that expanded the safety net and nudged us towards less income/wealth inequality?
What if the extreme Tea Party wing of the Republican party dissolved after annihilating itself in the 2016 election?
What if Tom Friedman stopped framing every argument with false equivalences and instead chose to lay the blame squarely on those responsible?
The first few are possible, but getting Tom Friedman to change his framing is impossible.

newswire.abstract: A new report suggests that we’re on the cusp of important, necessary changes in the way colleges evaluate applicants.

comments.commentBody:
Bruni correctly notes that the changes recommended in this report will move ahead and alter the college admissions process. However he concludes, "But they still need to stop filling so much of each freshman class with specially tagged legacy cases and athletes and to quit worrying about rankings like those of U.S. News and World Report. Only then will the tide fully turn."

And therein lies the keys. Until colleges stop chasing rankings and athletes and fill slots with legacy applicants, the changes will be minuscule even if in the right direction. But to "get the thrilling sense that something bigger is about to give" there needs to be these three key changes absent which it will neither be thrilling nor big.

newswire.abstract: Reality-based conservatives should mobilize against the hijacking of our party.

comments.commentBody:
"In politics, if A (Trump) and B (Cruz) savage each other then the benefits often go to Candidate C. But there has to be a C, not a C, D, E, F and G."

This reminded me of the iconic scene at the end of the spaghetti western "The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly" from the 1960s in which the three characters referred to in the title stand in a triangular formation in an attempt to win the buried treasure. Nobody wants to shoot lest they get shot at and killed. It is tense drama that concludes with the Good (Clint Eastwood) winning. But that is the movies, and one can take the story any which way. This is real life; there is no Good. Not even Bad. Only Ugly and Uglier. Maybe there is an Ugliest who can complete the trio.

"My overall sense: Clinton stronger on foreign policy, but on domestic issues, Sanders stronger. She showed nuance; he showed passion."

This is a pretty good less-than-140-characters-summary. The more important question is which one of them is more likely to deliver on their proposals. After all they are fighting for the job of POTUS, not EOA or emperor of America.

newswire.title: Donald Trump’s Existential Pickle
newswire.abstract: The egomaniacal billionaire has something on the line in Iowa that no other Republican does.

comments.commentBody:
"Trump asserts that he’s qualified because voters have affirmed him, or at least because they seem poised to."

In other words the marketplace is the ultimate arbiter that separates winners from losers. Those of us old enough will remember that pet rocks were huge winners, way back at the end of the last century, but I suspect nobody in the same marketplace called it a useful product. It was transient fun, something that you chuckled and enjoyed for a fleeting period of time. Until it became extinct, oops, a loser.

So too will The Donald. Welcome to the marketplace that props you up high on a pedestal until it doesn't.

newswire.title: Why I Always Wanted to Be a Secretary
newswire.abstract: My grandmother didn’t just teach me to type, but how to rise above others’ disregard.

comments.commentBody:
Titles have a fashion life cycle just like clothes, music, foods, and many other things in life. As part of that fashion life cycle a secretary is referred to as an administrative assistant in some places and office manager in others.
This is no different from the transition away from air hostess to stewards to flight attendants. Or the move away from the term janitor to custodian. Likewise we don't refer to the person selling you stuff as a sales clerk; instead we refer to them as customer service agents.
These changes may be a feeble attempt to "to make our work more dignified" but they also reflect a changing fashion cycle.

Politics: Everything’s Relative
Why Spin Is Good for Democracy
Why I Will Never Vote for Donald Trump
Ted Cruz Didn’t Disclose Loan From Goldman Sachs for His First Senate Campaign

newswire.abstract: Is he ruthless enough to win?

comments.commentBody:
Douthat blithely notes "Yet the Democratic campaign has attracted none of the “This Is Chaos!” coverage that’s attended the Republican primary season, none of the garment-rending among pundits and political insiders, none of the talk about civil wars and permanent schisms and a party that may never be the same."

What he fails to note is that there IS actual chaos and nonsense and falsehoods being uttered by the slate of Republican wannabees. Watching the GOP debates is grating unless one is lobotomized. There is hyperbole flying around at such a fast rate that one's head spins before fainting for lack of oxygen. Each one tops the other's falsity and raises some, as though it were a poker game.

OTOH the Democratic debate maintains a sane and civil tone. Real issues are brought up. Progressives like what Douthat calls "Obama-esque nods to complexity" but fails to note that real-world issues are indeed complex. There is no simple way to build a wall along the southern border and get the Mexican to pay for it, as Trump would have us believe. There is no simple way to admit just the Christians, as Bush would have us believe. And cooking bacon on the barrel of a rifle is not the method preferred by most Americans, including those owning guns.

The bottom line is that Douthat's dismissal of the Democratic platform, in general, and Sanders' in particular, is simplistic; the issues themselves are complex.

newswire.abstract: Here are rules for dealing with family members showing up in the presidential race, like when to give them a break and when to go for the jugular.

comments.commentBody:
There is always an inherent asymmetry in the candidate's proxies, whether family or otherwise, saying anything. If it is seen as appealing to a large segment, the candidate can jump on it and take credit for that statement. If it is seen as incendiary and seen as not appealing, the candidate can remain mute or aggressively distance him/herself depending on the severity of the statement.

And that is being fully exploited in all these cases. But none so smoothly as Ted Cruz, whose father wanted to send Obama back to Kenya but does not want to send his own son back to Canada. Maybe he think there is a wall between Canada and the USA.

newswire.abstract: Smug, mean and in the lead, Donald Trump and Ted Cruz are rewriting the rules of likability.

comments.commentBody:
B runi correctly notes that "Anger can have a noble dimension — as a response to injustice, as the grist for change — and neither Trump nor Cruz projects much nobility or tries to, for that matter. They’re not so much angry as petulant, impudent."

At long last here, for the first time, we are hearing that anger is not always a positive force although it can be ONLY if directed FOR a right cause AT a right target. And neither Trump nor Cruz fits that mold. Theirs is untrammeled anger that is more like a shot gun that sprays on any convenient target. And that is dangerous, not constructive.

newswire.abstract: I will not campaign for, vote for or support any candidate, even in my own party, who does not support common-sense gun reform.

comments.commentBody:
"If a child can’t open a bottle of aspirin, we should also make sure she can’t pull the trigger of a gun."
No one is calling for blocking the sale of aspirin, just that it be made safe. Isn't that common sense? Of course the NRA - No Responsibility or Accountability - has been opposing any common sense regulations in spite of the fact that the vast majority of Americans, including gun owners, are in favor of such regulations.
President Obama lamented thus, "It won’t happen during my presidency." But don't fret Mr. President, You will forever be known as The-One-Who-Gave-Us-Healthcare and The-One-Who-Spearheaded-Sensible-Gun-Legislation. Meanwhile the Greedy-Old-Party will go down the sinkhole along with the No-Responsibility-or-Accountability group.

What they forget is that these high numbers actually translate to no more than 5%-8% of the American population. Looked at it that way it should be hardly surprising that there is that sliver of the citizens who are racist or bigoted. End of story.

newswire.title: Trump Did Not Break Politics
newswire.abstract: Other politicians remade the rules right in front of our eyes.

comments.commentBody:
“Americans hate Congress, but love their own member of Congress.” The second half of this folk wisdom about politics and American citizenry is being challenged because a greater number (40%) than in the past disapprove of their own senator or representative.
In spite of their constituents' approval or disapproval senator or representative continue to be reelected. This is primarily due to redistricting or gerrymandering. And therein lies the real problem. Our representatives continue to carve districts that would win were they playing a game of Twister.
It is high time that redistricting were under the purview of a neutral independent authority. And since these come under the purview of states there is no inherent incentive for any state to cede control to such an authority. It is time to call for a national referendum and a constitutional amendment.

newswire.title: Elections Have Consequences
newswire.abstract: The difference that 2012 made shows us the stakes involved in 2016.

comments.commentBody:
These are no small achievements. And thanks to the good professor many of the NYT readers are now aware of the same.

But the stakes in the 2016 election are not just about defending these victories or expanding upon them. They are far more stark and include the appointment of at least 2 or 3 to the Supreme Court, honoring and enforcing the multi-country Iran nuclear deal without cavalierly starting yet another war in the Middle east, working to implement and further advance the global climate change deal struck in Paris, continuing to strengthen the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, and much much more.

As you can see the stakes are very high. And the best thing for progressives to do is to themselves vote and then help get out the vote.

newswire.abstract: In professional sports, where slurs are still tolerated, acting as if your homosexuality was never a secret is a bold counteroffensive move.

comments.commentBody:
Isn't it strange that the things that ought to matter the least seem to matter the most. What does it matter if someone is gay or not? What does it matter if someone is Christian, Muslim, Jew, Hindu, Buddhist or atheist? What does it matter if someone is Caucasoid, Mongoloid, Negroid or some yet to be discovered anthropological categorizing scheme? What does it matter if like dogs, cats, gerbils or any other pet?
There are so many more interesting and important issues in this world and yet some of us choose to focus on these minutiae. Sad, very sad.

newswire.title: India and Pakistan Try Again
newswire.abstract: Will the warm handclasp of Narendra Modi and Nawaz Sharif lead to progress on delicate issues that have long divided their two countries?

comments.commentBody:
Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif may be personally interested in better relations with India but unfortunately he is a mere puppet in the government that is essentially and effectively run by the Pakistani army. Here is a list of recent events that the Pakistani army is complicit in:
1. Giving refuge to the Taliban, especially Osama Bin laden.
2. Facilitating infiltration into the Indian state of Kashmir to destabilize the local government and introduce chaos in the citizenry.
3. Turning a blind eye when the A. Q. Khan sold nuclear technology to renegade states like North Korea, Libya, Iraq and Iran.
4. The Pakistani army was directly involved in planning and executing the terrorist attacks in Mumbai just a few years back.

I could go on and on as this is an endless list. To label the Pakistani military a terrorist organization would not be untrue. Even as of yesterday there was an attack by terrorists, obviously aided and abetted by the Pakistani military, on the Pathankot AFB that killed three Indian army personnel.

The duplicity of Pakistani army is well known and yet Pakistan is one of America's BFF, receiving a great deal of military aid. Is it too much to ask the American administration to cut back the aid? This will go a long way in stifling the powerful army and help bring the Pakistani government to the negotiating table. America has that strong lever to use; isn't it high time to use it?

comments.commentBody:
Douthat is curmudgeonly in pointing out that "ISIS probably won't endure" and breathlessly notes that "Trump will not be the Republican nominee (yes, really)." What he fails to mention is that both these phenomena fleeting or otherwise were seeded, watered and lovingly nurtured by the likes of Douthat.
And now to place the blame for these phenomena on the doorsteps of liberalism is not cowardice but pure malice. Shame on you Sir!

newswire.abstract: Technology is finally back to advancing our ability to produce and deliver things.

comments.commentBody:
Prof. Krugman notes, "We are still living in a material world, and pushing information around can do only so much."
He forgot to mention that pushing around money or no-fee mortgages, as the Wall Street boys did, can do (and did) worse - It almost wrecked the economy.
So, I for one, along with the good professor, am cheerful this holiday season that we are getting science back to where it belongs - front and center.

Snoqualmie Falls in Snoqualmie, Washington.
Snoqualmie Falls in Snoqualmie, Washington.
Snoqualmie Falls in Snoqualmie, Washington.

newswire.abstract: You think about all the places that need water, and all the places that have too much — and you wonder whether the new normal is the scary normal.

comments.commentBody:
One of the reasons we the people are blase about the current situation is because of the phenomenon many readers of the NYT will know - The Tragedy of the Commons. Simply put, we do not believe that each one of us doing a little will add up to a whole lot and hence each one of us merrily continues doing whatever and hoping that others will pick up the slack. Our collective doom is thus ensured.
Most humans are hardwired thus and so it is important to constantly put pressure on our politicians so that at least they can be nudged to move in the right direction. Sadly with the current crop of politicians in America (especially but not exclusively the GOP) that too seems impossible.

comments.commentBody:
"In summary: Kill the families. Screw the orphans. Carpet-bomb Syria, but in a targeted way. Send Jeb Bush a dollar. On to 2016."
This is the best ending ever. Let me try a little mix myself.
Fiorina - Kill the mother but save the fetus.
Christie - I know of yet another way to hold back kids from school, just close off a tunnel and maybe a bridge or two as well.
Trump - Watch me color my hair three different ways, with my pencil, brush or comb.
Cruz - Too many roaches in my motel. Carpet bomb them, but please save my show that is on the floor.
Jeb! - Here's a dollar, now go and buy your brother a seat in the White House.

newswire.title: Paris Climate Accord Is a Big, Big Deal
newswire.abstract: The agreement means we have a chance to avoid unmanageable effects of global warming and to handle the effects we can’t avoid.

comments.commentBody:
Thanx Mr. Friedman for this column that nails down three things very very clearly.

1. President Obama and Secretary Kerry deserve all the credit you can give them. Without their leadership and persuasive abilities, this agreement could not have been achieved.

2. Other than the Republicans the entire world is on board this deal. This holdout caps the seven years of disruptive politics they have practiced. I can only surmise that they do not care much for the only place on earth we call home.

3. As Friedman so eloquently notes, "one of these knuckleheads could be our next president and mess this up." It is up to us to vote and help get out the vote so that none of these knuckleheads has a chance of getting within a mile of the White House.

newswire.abstract: Healing from traumatic memories is an intensely difficult and complex process, but it is possible, for nations as well as individuals.

comments.commentBody:
"If one person in a conversation takes the rhetorical level up to 10 every time, the other person has to rebut at Level 10 and turn monstrous, or retreat into resentful silence. Rhetorical passion, which feels so good, can destroy conversation and mar truth and reconciliation."

This is a perfect description of the GOP, in general, and its TP wing, in particular. And The Donald sits atop all of this. Not that Ben Carson is far behind. I've lost track of the number of times he has compared Obamacare or anything other progressive initiative to what the Nazis would have done. Clearly these take the rhetorical level beyond level 10.

I smiled as I read this paragraph wondering if this is David's soft criticism of his tribe. If so, I'd advice him to step up his rhetorical level, for otherwise it'll not register with members of his tribe.

newswire.title: Trump’s Weimar America
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
newswire.abstract: It would be foolish not to take Trump seriously. The unthinkable has happened in Europe. It's not impossible in America.

comments.commentBody:
Cohen correctly points that we cannot disregard Trump as a carnival barker. He writes, "And he’s onto something. It is foolish not to take him seriously." He repeats himself and notes, "It would be foolish and dangerous not to take him seriously. His bombast is attuned to Weimar America."

The key idea is that Trump is onto "something." What is that thing? years of globalization, foolish wars, an African-American President, an influx of terrorism on American soil have all combined to make a class of Americans weary and scared of their own future. That is the strain that Trump has latched onto. Of course there are better answers to the problems faced by this class of Americans who find themselves alienated in their own country. But with a recalcitrant GOP in control of the Congress we are unable to enact common-sense legislation that would go a long way to alleviate the troubles felt by this group of Americans. And in the absence of that, they have grabbed onto Trump's bombast. And the scary part is that unless his GOP compatriots begin to cut him down, he'll grow bigger.
But Trump, in spite of being the speaker and messenger, is not solely responsible for where we are. For that we have to thank the GOP and its Tea Party members who have seeded, watered and nurtured the growth of this hostility. As you sow, so you reap.

newswire.title: First Time at a Gun Show
newswire.abstract: What could be a civilized debate about personal protection is too often poisoned by the gun lobby.

comments.commentBody:
We also have stores selling chemicals - they are variously called drug stores, fertilizer stores, paint stores, etc. Many regular normal folk go to this store and buy these materials for their daily use. But their purchases (for the most part) are regulated. These regulations are not intended to take away these chemicals from normal Americans, they are intended to make the American home and public spaces safer.
Why can't the same logic be applied to guns?

newswire.abstract: The 2010 death of Leonard Strickland would have probably been forgotten by all but the officers and inmates at Clinton Correctional Facility. Then a breakout brought attention to the prison’s secrets.

comments.commentBody:
This is a sad, very sad, story. And it seems many of the prison guards mete harsh punishment that is at the very least borderline abusive.
These stories repeat themselves from county to county and state to state. While holding prison guards and policemen accountable is important, they are the smaller cogs in the wheels of the justice system. As others have commented, Governor Cuomo is heading the list of responsible officials who turn a blind eye in the name of order and control.
Likewise we have Rahm Emmanuel, mayor of Chicago, who after one full year has the temerity to fie the police chief but take no responsibility himself. He is shamelessly clinging on to his job.
As is often the case it is the underlings that get caught while the top bosses get away with not even a slap on the wrist. The buck always must stop at the top.

As Kristof has shown there are passages in all religious scriptures that we find reprehensible today. Clearly we need to be able and willing to read these words in context and not as though they are literally applicable today.
As an aside the same holds true of our reading of the constitution, a document that is much much younger to these religious writings.
